title: Reading Comprehension Strategies

vocab.kid_friendly_definition: The most important point in a story or paragraph.
Small pieces of information that support the main idea.
A guess about what might happen next in a story.
Hints in the words and sentences around an unknown word that help you figure out its meaning.
To make a picture in your mind while reading.
To tell the main points in a short way.
Asking who, what, when, where, why, or how while you read.

teachingNotes: Use simple stories and picture books. Practice asking 'who, what, when, where, why' questions. Model thinking aloud while reading.

sample.question: What should you do if you don't understand a word while reading?
expectedAny: look for clues in the sentence

truefalse.question: Good readers think about what they're reading as they read.
expectedAny: active reading involves thinking about the text

multiplechoice.question: What is the main idea of a story about a dog who saves a cat from a tree?
expectedAny: the main action is the dog helping the cat

fillintheblank.question: Before you read a story, you can look at the pictures to make a _____ about what might happen.

shortanswer.question: What are three things you can do to better understand what you read?
